title-group.article-title: The effect of electromagnetic stirring and cerium addition on dry sliding reciprocating wear of hypereutectic aluminium–silicon alloy

abstract.p: Influences of electromagnetic stirring (EMS) and rare earth (RE) CeO2 addition on reciprocating wear behaviour of hypereutectic Al–Si alloys have been presented in this article. Reciprocating wear tests were carried out at different contact loads (from 15 to 90 N) and speeds (from 0.2 to 1.0 m/s) using pin-on-plate configuration for a constant sliding distance of 500 m. It was observed that EMS and RE (CeO2) addition refined the microstructure and improved the hardness. EMS reduced the wear rates of hypereutectic Al–Si alloy irrespective of applied load and sliding velocity. Transition from mild to severe wear was observed in as-cast alloy at 90 N normal load (constant sliding velocity = 0.4 m/s). Scanning electron microscopy of worn surfaces and wear debris was carried out to study the wear mechanism of material removal under different sliding conditions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hypereutectic aluminium–silicon (Al--Si) alloys are widely used all over the globe due to their light weight, good castability, corrosion resistance and high strength-to-weight ratio.1 These alloys are best suited in automobile industry for manufacturing tribological components like cylinder heads and pistons. For such applications, wear resistance and other tribological properties are required. Therefore, efforts are being made for improving the wear resistance of these alloys using various approaches such as adding alloying elements, improving casting techniques, heat treatments and reinforcing hard micro-constituents.2 All these methods of enhancing the wear resistance of an alloy are primarily based on the modification of structure to achieve desired properties.1,3 These methods can be applied either in single or in combination to improve the properties.

Additions of rare earth (RE) elements reduce gases generated during casting and improve mechanical properties by solid solution strengthening and precipitation hardening.4–6 Further, mechanical properties such as hardness, in turn, can increase the applied normal load and speed (velocity) of tribological components and enhance the wear resistance. Moreover, dry sliding reciprocating conditions cause more wear than continuous sliding conditions.2 So, it becomes essential to study some new alloying element that improves the wear resistance in dry sliding reciprocating conditions. Addition of RE elements such as CeO2 has been reported to improve the mechanical and tribological properties of Al–Si alloys by refining eutectic silicon and primary silicon particles (PSPs).7,8 Rare earth CeO2 primarily refines the eutectic silicon better than PSPs. PSPs can be further refined by some processing method such as semi-solid processing.

Electromagnetic stirring (EMS) is a newer method of semi-solid processing and has shown promising results on refinement and spheroidization of microstructure of Al–Si alloys.9–11 Literature survey has revealed that no attempts have been made to study the influence of combination of EMS process and CeO2 addition in hypereutectic Al–Si alloys on dry sliding wear behaviour under reciprocating conditions.1–2,12 So, it is very important to investigate the adhesive wear behaviour of alloys to be used for wear applications.13,14 Therefore, an attempt has been made to study the adhesive wear behaviour of a combination of CeO2 modified hypereutectic Al–Si alloy subjected to EMS in dry sliding reciprocating conditions.

sec.title: Experimental procedure
sec.p:
The Al–16 (wt%) Si alloy used in this study was prepared by melting Al–50% Si master alloy and pure Al ingot in an induction furnace. This alloy was modified by adding CeO2 (0.2 wt%) in molten condition. The temperature of the molten metal was maintained at 850°C for 30 min before pouring the melt and the molten metal was treated with cover flux and degasser for removing impurities and gases. The following alloy designations were used in various plots (Table 1). Table 1.
Alloy conditions and designations used.
S. no Alloy descriptions Conditions Designations used
1. Al–16 (wt%) Si As-cast U16
2. Al–16 (wt%) Si Subjected to EMS S16
3. Al–16 (wt%) Si + CeO2 (0.2 wt%) As-cast CU
4. Al–16 (wt%) Si + CeO2 (0.2 wt%) Subjected to EMS CS

sec.title: Wear testing
sec.p:
A reciprocating wear test rig conforming to ASTM standard G-133-05 was used to investigate the dry sliding adhesive wear behaviour of alloys in as-cast, EMS-cast, as-cast modified by CeO2 and EMS-cast modified by CeO2 conditions, as shown in Figure 1. A grey cast iron plate (250 HVN) was used as a counter surface having surface roughness (Ra) of 0.21 µm. Initial and final weights of wear pins subjected to reciprocating wear were measured by an electronic weight balance with a least count of 0.0001. Contact load was applied to the wear pins by a dead weight using a lever system. Dry sliding wear tests under reciprocating conditions were performed by applying contact load in the range 15–90 N and average reciprocating velocity in the range 0.2–1.0 m/s. Weight loss criteria were used for calculating the wear of material. Wear rate (g/m) was calculated from ratio of weight (in grams) and sliding distance (in meters). For each wear test, wear pins were cleaned with acetone and weighed after running through a constant sliding distance of 500 m. To maintain identical sliding conditions, the counter surface was polished to a surface roughness less than 0.3 µm. Scanning electron microscopy of the debris and wear surfaces was done to study the wear mechanism under different sliding conditions. Figure 1.
Schematic of reciprocating wear test rig.

sec.title: Metallurgical characteristics
sec.p:
Optical microscopic studies of as-cast and EMS-cast alloys modified by CeO2 primarily revealed polyhedral-shaped PSPs, a mixture of Al–Si eutectic in the matrix of aluminium (Figure 2(a) and (b)). Image analysis of various micro-constituents present in the microstructure of alloy under different conditions showed that morphology (in respect of average size and aspect ratio) of PSPs is significantly influenced by CeO2 modification and EMS. It can be observed that EMS-cast alloy modified by CeO2 reduces the average size of PSPs (from 284 to 76.87 µm) and aspect ratio (from 2.68 to 1.32). Reduction in aspect ratio indicates that PSPs tend to spheroidize. Further, electromagnetic stirring (EMS) of CeO2 modified alloy appreciably increased hardness (from 98.5 to 122.66 BHN). Refinement of PSPs, reduction in aspect ratio and increase in hardness owing to EMS-cast alloy modified by CeO2 are expected to enhance the wear resistance of an alloy. Figure 2.
(a) and (b): Optical micrographs of as-cast alloy and EMS + CeO2 modified alloys.

sec.title: Wear behaviour
sec.p:
Initially, a trial run of dry sliding wear test under reciprocating condition was carried out to identify the sliding distance required for achieving the steady-state condition, so that the other tests can be conducted to investigate the wear performance of an alloy in different conditions (Figure 3). It can be observed that an increase in sliding distance increases wear but at a decreasing rate until steady state is achieved, as indicated by the negative slope of wear vs. sliding distance curve. Plot indicates that steady-state condition is attained after 500 m of sliding distance. Therefore, in this study, all wear tests were carried out at a sliding distance of 500 m. Figure 3.
Wear rate vs sliding distance plot.

sec.title: Effect of alloy conditions and contact load on wear
sec.p:
The effect of alloy conditions (as-cast, EMS-cast, as-cast modified by CeO2 and EMS-cast modified by CeO2) on wear behaviour under varying load conditions is shown in Figure 4. It can be observed that as-cast alloy is subjected to higher wear rates than EMS-cast alloy modified by CeO2 irrespective of applied normal load. The conditions of alloy having wear rate in decreasing order is given as follows: as-cast, EMS-cast, as-cast modified by CeO2 and EMS-cast modified by CeO2. Further, it can be noticed that the effect of alloy condition on wear rate is more at higher load (above 45 N) than low loads. Moreover, EMS-cast alloy modified by CeO2 results in significant reduction in wear rate especially at high normal loads i.e. 60, 75 and 90 N. In general, an increase in normal load increases the wear rate irrespective of alloy condition (Figures 4 and 5). A bar chart showing the comparative wear behaviour of an alloy as a function of normal load in different alloy conditions indicates that EMS-cast alloy modified by CeO2 significantly lowers the wear rate compared to as-cast alloy (Figure 5). It can also be noticed that an increase in normal load from 15 to 45 N causes a linear increase in the wear rate of as-cast alloy. Thereafter, further increase in load from 60 to 90 N abruptly increases the wear rate. Increase in normal load (from 15 to 90 N) linearly increases the wear rate of EMS-cast alloy modified by CeO2 without any sharp change in wear behaviour. The change in slope of wear rate vs. normal load curve for as-cast alloy (above 45 N load) indicates the transition in the mode of wear from mild oxidative regime to severe metallic wear regime. This trend suggests that EMS-cast alloy modified by CeO2 is more coherent and stable under dry sliding wear conditions than as-cast alloy. Figure 4.
Wear rate vs load for various alloys (v = 0.4 m/s). Figure 5.
Comparison of wear rates of U16 and CS (v = 0.4 m/s).

sec.title: Effect of alloy conditions and reciprocating velocity on wear
sec.p:
The effect of alloy conditions (EMS-cast, as-cast modified by CeO2 and EMS-cast modified by CeO2) on the wear behaviour under varying reciprocating velocity conditions is shown in Figure 6. It can be observed that, in general, the effect of alloy condition on wear behaviour under varying reciprocating velocity conditions is similar to that of varying contact load conditions because the as-cast alloy under varying reciprocating velocity conditions is also subjected to higher wear rates than the EMS-cast alloy modified by CeO2 irrespective of reciprocating velocity. The alloy condition has been found to significantly influence wear rate under different reciprocating velocities, and the alloy conditions in the decreasing order of wear rate are given as follows: as-cast, EMS-cast, as-cast modified by CeO2 and EMS-cast modified by CeO2. Moreover, the effect of the alloy condition on wear rate is more at low reciprocating velocity (<0.8 m/s) than high reciprocating velocity (>1.0 m/s). Moreover, the EMS and RE modification of alloy results in significant reduction in wear rate especially at low reciprocating velocity i.e. from 0.2 to 0.8 m/s. In general, an increase in reciprocating velocity linearly decreases the wear rate irrespective of alloy condition (Figures 6 and 7). A bar chart showing comparative wear behaviour of the alloys in different conditions as a function of reciprocating velocity shows that EMS-cast alloy modified by CeO2 significantly decreases the wear rate as compared to that of the as-cast one (Figure 7). Figure 6.
Wear rate vs velocity for various alloys (load = 30 N). Figure 7.
Comparison of wear rates of U16 and CS (load = 30 N).

sec.title: Scanning electron micrograph study
sec.p:
Scanning electron micrographs (SEM) of wear debris generated during the sliding wear test (conducted under different sliding conditions) of as-cast and EMS-cast alloys modified by CeO2 are shown in Figure 8. It can be observed that EMS-cast alloy modified by CeO2 has produced very fine and powdery particles (Figure 8(b)) during the wear test while, very coarse and elongated laminates were produced (Figure 8(a)) during the sliding wear test of as-cast alloy at 15 N load. EMS-cast alloy modified by CeO2 also produced finer debris even at high load (90 N) (Figure 8(c)). Debris of the as-cast base alloy and CeO2 modified and EMS cast alloys at 0.2 m/s are shown in Figure 8(d) and (e). It can be observed that the as-cast base alloy produced some large size laminates due to high wear (at velocity = 0.2 m/s), whereas EMS-cast alloy modified by CeO2 produced comparatively finer debris due to low wear (at velocity 0.2 m/s). Figure 8.
(a) to (e) SEM images of wear debris of as cast base alloy at 15 N, EMS + CeO2 modified alloy at 15 N, EMS + CeO2 modified alloy at 90 N, as-cast base alloy at V = 0.2 m/s and EMS + CeO2 modified alloy at V = 0.2 m/s respectively.

In the case of hypereutectic alloys, the basic phenomenon for the formation of wear debris is the mutual transfer of the material. Debris are produced in these alloys when a comparatively softer material has some harder area, the harder material has some softer area and these two areas come in contact with each other; the harder one pulls out a laminate from the softer material.15 When one of the areas in contact has coarse, hard and brittle region like the one observed in our case, the as-cast and unmodified hypereutectic alloys have coarse PSPs. Then, the laminates produced are large and elongated ones, as evident from the SEM of the wear debris of the as-cast base alloy without modification and EMS (Figure 8(a)). Application of EMS and modification of CeO2 refined the microstructure and reduced the size of coarse PSPs that produced very fine powdery laminates at low load (15 N) (Figure 8(b)) and small size laminates even at high load (90 N) (Figure 8(c)). These findings are in agreement with wear test results. The form of wear debris suggests the occurrence of mild oxidative wear under these sliding conditions (low load and high load).

SEMs of wear surfaces generated during sliding wear test (conducted under different sliding conditions) of as-cast and EMS-cast alloys modified by CeO2 are shown in Figure 9. In general, SEMs of wear surfaces show abrasive marks, wear scars, craters, ridges and oxidized surfaces irrespective of alloy conditions. SEM of wear surfaces of the as-cast base alloy and EMS cast alloy modified by CeO2 are shown in Figure 9(a) and (b) at 90 N load, respectively. It can be observed that the worn surface of as-cast base alloy shows mainly wear craters and oxidation (Figure 9(a)), whereas the worn surfaces of CeO2 modified and EMS cast alloy (Figure 9(b)) show comparatively smoother surface along with signs of oxidation. The presence of surface craters at worn surfaces suggests that the material has been removed from that place in the form of laminates. Some granular kind of delamination can also be observed inside and outside wear craters where small granules of the material have been deposited, as shown in the SEM (Figure 9(c)) of wear surface of as-cast alloy at high velocity = 1.0 m/s.16 The worn surfaces of the CeO2 modified and EMS processed alloy (Figure 9(d)) at V = 1.0 m/s show comparatively smoother surface than those of as-cast and unmodified alloys, which implies that wear damage was lesser than that of as-cast alloy due to lesser time available for cold weld bonding and heating up of the worn surface at high speeds. There are lesser number of contact points on the two surfaces in contact and consequently lesser or mild wear at high velocities. These results further confirm that wear surfaces of EMS-cast alloy modified by CeO2 are harder, stronger and more coherent than those of the as-cast alloy and also in agreement with wear test results. Figure 9.
(a) to (d) SEM images of worn surfaces of as-cast base alloy at 90 N, EMS + CeO2 modified at 90 N, as-cast base alloy at V = 1.0 m/s and EMS + CeO2 modified alloy at V = 1.0 m/s respectively.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: EMS of alloys promotes the formation of fine-grained and spheroidal grain structures of alpha-Al besides refinement of PSPs. Rare earths reduce oxygen and hydrogen contents in metallic materials, which in turn reduces blow holes and pin holes, refines microstructure and improves distribution of elements.5,6 EMS of alloys combined with RE CeO2 shows reduction in the average size of PSPs and average aspect ratio of the alloy. Reduction of such microstructural features in a structure improves the hardness and wear properties of an alloy.7 Rare earth CeO2 also form intermetallic compounds like AlCe and CeO2 with hypereutectic Al–Si alloys that remain unmixed in the structure.4

Aluminium alloys at low loads and speeds form a mechanically mixed layer (MML) primarily composed of oxides of elements from interacting surfaces under reciprocating sliding conditions.17 MML increases the hardness of wear surface, which predominantly influences the mechanism of wear between the interacting surfaces. According to delamination theory, all the factors such as mechanical properties and morphology of micro-constituents present in an alloy facilitate the easy removal of MML from wear surface in the form of laminates (by crack nucleation and growth processes) and generally increase the wear.18 Micro-constituents present in hypereutectic Al–Si alloys include alpha aluminium, eutectic mixture and PSPs besides some other intermetallic compounds such as CuAl2, Mg2Si and Al5SiFe. In general, size and shape (high aspect ratio) of hard and brittle micro-constituents such as eutectic and PSPs, Mg2Si and Al5SiFe affect the crack nucleation and growth tendency at hard particles–matrix interfaces and they are known to increase the delamination tendency as they encourage crack nucleation and growth tendency.1 As hard and brittle intermetallic compounds and coarse PSPs offer high stress concentration at the tips of needle–matrix interface, this may be the primary reason for higher wear rates of an alloy in as-cast condition without EMS process and RE addition. EMS process and RE CeO2 modification of the alloy used in this study lead to mild wear even at high loads/low speeds (velocity) (Figures 4 to 7). The transformation of coarse PSPs into comparatively fine PSPs with low aspect ratio in alloys modified with RE addition and processed by EMS significantly lowers the adhesive wear because short and blocky PSPs decrease the stress concentration at particle–matrix interface and crack nucleation and growth tendency, which in turn lowers the formation of laminates by delamination.

list-item.p: EMS process and CeO2 addition have reduced the average size of PSP from 284 to 76.87 µm and average aspect ratio from 2.68 to 1.32 and refined the microstructure described in this study.
EMS process and CeO2 addition have increased hardness from 98.50 to 122.66 BHN and improved the wear resistance (followed Archard’s law)

EMS process and CeO2 addition have significantly decreased the wear rates at all loads from 15 to 90 N (constant reciprocating velocity = 0.4 m/s) and at all velocities from 0.2 to 1.0 m/s (constant load = 30 N) at a constant sliding distance of 500 m.
SEMs of wear debris and worn surfaces (EMS process and CeO2 addition) exhibited mild and oxidative wear regime. Delamination was the mechanism observed for wear.
